item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the Gap at the Carriage Servo Pulley Bearing
item.description:
During the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, significant longitudinal play was discovered in the threaded rod responsible for moving the carriage. This play resulted in a ‘clacking’ noise whenever the carriage changed direction. The issue was resolved by removing the servo pulley, damaged locking ring, and worn plastic washer. A new, thick 2-56 nylon washer, which fit snugly on the shaft, replaced the locking ring and washer. The locking ring became unnecessary as the pulley was secured with a setscrew...

item.description:

item.title: Beogram 4000: Increasing Tonearm Lowering Delay
item.description:
After installing a new hood on a Beogram 4000 turntable, the author noticed the tonearm descended too quickly. Adjusting the damper’s screw didn’t solve the problem, as the tonearm still dropped rapidly despite the damper slowing down. Further inspection revealed the damper’s linkage was positioned very close to the damper plunger. This proximity meant the linkage moved immediately when the damper activated, even before the damper could build up enough vacuum to slow the tonearm’s descent effectively...
